What do make then of the routine claim to be "infilled" made by so many of today's Evangelical Christians? I am told I am "spiritually blind" and so I thought it possible that it was the reason I can see no significant difference between those making the claim and other unfortified mortals.
Jo Bennett

I don't know what to make of their claims, I can't speak to the contents of other men's hearts. I suppose the best I can come up with is that we all, to a greater or lesser extent experience the Spirit at work within us, and one measure of our progress in faith might be the extent to which we embrace the work of the Spirit, so to be filled with the Holy Spirit means to take successfully manage what is prayed for in the words of the song: "let my life be yours and yet, let it still be me". So, when we are baptised or confirmed, depending on your understanding, we receive the Holy Spirit, but whether we could be said to be filled with it would rather depend on whether we have been successful in following Christ's commands.
